doc.previous: Tiruchirappalli has been recognised in India as an important educational centre since the time of British rule.[253][254][255] St. Joseph's College, which opened in Nagapattinam in 1846 and transferred to Tiruchirappalli in 1883, is one of the oldest educational institutions in South India.[256] The Society for the Propagation of the Gospel (SPG) college, established in 1883, is a premium missionary institution in the city.[253]
doc.after: As of 2013, Tiruchirappalli has 45 arts and science colleges, 40 polytechnic colleges and 13 colleges that offer management education.[257] The St. Joseph's College, National College,[258] Bishop Heber College,[259] Jamal Mohamed College[260] and the Government Law College are prominent colleges providing higher education in the arts and sciences.[261] There are approximately 35 engineering colleges in and around the city.[195] The National Institutes of Technology, established by the government in 1964 as the Regional Engineering College,[262] has a campus at Thuvakudi on the outskirts of Tiruchirappalli.[263]
